author: By Raymond Zhong
title: 5 Takeaways From the U.N. Report on Limiting Global Warming
description: Current pledges to cut emissions, even if nations follow through on them, won’t stop temperatures from rising to risky new levels.
content: Nations are not doing nearly enough to prevent global warming from increasing to dangerous levels within the lifetimes of most people on Earth today, according to a new report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, a group of researchers convened by the United Nations. Limiting the devastation won’t be easy, but it also isn’t impossible if countries act now, the report says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Sarah Palin Knows How to Get Attention. Can She Actually Win?
description: Endorsed by Donald Trump for Alaska’s lone House seat, the former vice-presidential candidate hopes she can mount a political comeback. But she’s not the phenomenon she once was.
content: The last time Sarah Palin and Donald Trump shared a stage together, the former Alaska governor gave a meandering endorsement speech that displayed her inventiveness with the English language — and her instinctive connection to the Republican base.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: deciduous
description: This word has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word deciduous has appeared in 12 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 8 in the book review “Did the First Americans Arrive via Land Bridge? This Geneticist Says No.” by Jeremy DeSilva:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Bidens Will Host a White House Wedding Reception for Their Granddaughter
description: Naomi Biden, 28, the daughter of Hunter Biden and Kathleen Buhle, will marry Peter Neal, 24, this fall.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden and Jill Biden, the first lady, plan to host a wedding reception this fall at the White House for their eldest granddaughter, Naomi Biden, who is set to marry her longtime boyfriend.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Jury Selection Begins in Sentencing Trial for Parkland Gunman
description: The process is expected to take weeks. Jurors will then sit through a lengthy trial to determine if the gunman should be sentenced to death or life in prison.
content: FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. — In the four years since a former student killed 17 people and injured 17 others in Parkland, Fla., the classroom building where the shooting took place has remained standing, unused and fenced off, on the grounds of Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Preston and Matt Cosby
title: The Search for a Model Octopus That Won’t Die After Laying Its Eggs
description: A lab in Massachusetts may have finally found an eight-armed cephalopod that can serve as a model organism and assist scientific research.
content: The tank looked empty, but turning over a shell revealed a hidden octopus no bigger than a Ping-Pong ball. She didn’t move. Then all at once, she stretched her ruffled arms as her skin changed from pearly beige to a pattern of vivid bronze stripes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Two More Republicans Back Jackson as Senate Moves Toward Confirmation
description: The support of Senators Mitt Romney and Lisa Murkowski for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination was a counterpoint to the bitterly partisan confirmation process so far.
content: WASHINGTON — A nearly unified wall of G.O.P. opposition to Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson cracked slightly on Monday as two more Senate Republicans said they would side with Democrats in supporting her, paving the way for her confirmation as the first Black woman on the Supreme Court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: A Georgia Restaurant Has a Racist History. What Should Become of It?
description: At Aunt Fanny’s Cabin, which closed years ago, young Black waiters sang for white patrons. The community is divided over how, and whether, to preserve the institution’s legacy.
content: SMYRNA, Ga. — For half a century, celebrities, tourists and local residents flocked to Aunt Fanny’s Cabin, a restaurant known as much for its Southern menu as for its depiction of plantation life and racist imagery, where white patrons were served by young Black waiters with yoke-like wooden menu boards hung around their necks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, Anna Schaverien and David F. Gallagher
title: Elon Musk’s Latest Twitter Adventure
description: The Tesla chief bought a big stake in the social media company. What’s his plan?
content: Shares of Twitter soared 25 percent in premarket trading on news that Elon Musk had personally bought a 9.2 percent stake in the social media company, making him its largest shareholder. The stake, revealed in a regulatory filing, was amassed before Musk criticized Twitter in — yes — a series of tweets, questioning the company’s commitment to “free speech” and wondering whether a new social media platform was needed. With more sway over the company, will he try to reinvent Twitter to be more to his liking?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli, Vanessa Friedman, Isabelia Herrera, Jon Pareles and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Best and Worst Moments From the 2022 Grammys
description: Young artists brought dramatic performances, Doja Cat had an emotional moment at the microphone and Volodymyr Zelensky recorded a serious plea from Ukraine.
content: The 64th annual Grammy Awards promised a return to (relative) normalcy following a scaled-down 2021 ceremony that largely took place outdoors. In Las Vegas for the first time, and with the pop spectacle dialed back up, the show’s most impactful moments were often its least flashy: a sober plea for help from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine; Doja Cat’s teary moment at the microphone; performances on rooftops that put a spotlight on a different crop of artists. (High-octane live moments from Billie Eilish and H.E.R. made a big impact, too.) Here are the show’s highlights and lowlights as we saw them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Perfecting Neapolitan Pizza in Los Angeles, With Help From Tokyo
description: At Pizzeria Sei, Sang Woo Joo uses global wisdom to nudge a rigid style into the future, one pie at a time.
content: LOS ANGELES — Every day, the pizza at Pizzeria Sei is a tiny bit different from the day before. I know this because I can’t stop going to Pizzeria Sei.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Cauterucci
title: The Human Shields of the Abortion Rights Movement
description: In “Bodies on the Line,” Lauren Rankin traces the civilian efforts to protect abortion seekers from those who would stand in their way.
content: BODIES ON THE LINE At the Front Lines of the Fight to Protect Abortion in AmericaBy Lauren Rankin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Coscarelli
title: Silk Sonic wins song of the year.
description: Bruno Mars, Anderson .Paak, Christopher Brody Brown and Dernst Emile II won for “Leave the Door Open.” Mars said, “Because of you guys, me and Andy gonna be singing this song forever.”
content: The first televised award of the night, following three elaborate performances, was a major one: “Leave the Door Open,” by the throwback soul and R&B duo Silk Sonic, won song of the year, a category with 10 total nominees and steep competition. The track peaked at No. 1 on the Billboard Hot 100 singles chart.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Anthony Johnston
title: Even a Broken Femur Can’t Stop Tony Hawk
description: A documentary chronicles the challenges of Hawk’s skating career. He sat down to discuss the devastating leg injury that made promoting it (and walking) a challenge.
content: While everyone’s attention was focused elsewhere, another thing happened at this year’s Oscars. Tony Hawk, the world’s most iconic skateboarder, unveiled his latest trick: Standing without a cane.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlotta Gall
title: ‘Sitting at Home and Trembling.’ A Town Emerges After a Russian Retreat.
description: A local official said he was detained and interrogated by the Russians, and described what he called mock executions.
content: NOVA BASAN, Ukraine — Badly frightened and hungry, residents of Nova Basan, a town east of Kyiv, emerged from their cottages and farmhouses on Monday, and described living through the terrifying ordeal of the Russian occupation — detentions, threats and a strict curfew that confined them to their homes with no outside communication for more than a month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Why Are Seemingly Functional Adults Falling for the ‘Furries’ Myth?
description: The culture war is also a generational war.
content: A Nebraska state senator, Bruce Bostelman, last month warned of an alarming new variety of deviance making its way into the state’s schools. “It’s something called furries,” he said. Schoolchildren, Bostelman claimed, were identifying as cats or dogs. “They meow and they bark.” And educators, indulging them, “are wanting to put litter boxes in the schools for the children to use,” said Bostelman.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: Western Officials Condemn Reports of ‘Massacre’ by Military in Central Mali
description: The State Department and the French foreign ministry said they were alarmed at reports of deaths caused by the Malian armed forces and their allies — Russian mercenaries with the Wagner Group.
content: DAKAR, Senegal — French, American and European officials have expressed serious concerns about allegations that hundreds of people were killed last week in a town in the West African nation of Mali by Malian soldiers accompanied by Russian mercenaries on a campaign to fight insurgents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: The Best Game That Money Could Buy
description: A contentious lockout came in the middle of an off-season with record spending. The gaps between the richest and poorest clubs have only grown wider.
content: Money doesn’t buy championships, but it certainly helps.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Green
title: Review: In ‘Paradise Square,’ Racial Harmony Turns to Discord
description: In a new musical starring Joaquina Kalukango, the love between Black and Irish New Yorkers in a Manhattan bar is threatened by Civil War riots.
content: Everything in “Paradise Square” is true. Nothing in “Paradise Square” is true.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Reports of Russian atrocities.
content: Growing evidence of Russian atrocities against civilians in Ukraine has brought home the horrific toll of the war, prompting world leaders to threaten even harsher sanctions, including a lockout of Russia’s vital gas industry, a step some had been loath to take. Follow the latest updates from the war and maps of the invasion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eileen Sullivan
title: ICE Lawyers Directed to Clear Low-Priority Immigration Cases
description: The effort could significantly reduce a backlog of asylum and deportation cases as the Biden administration anticipates a huge surge of migrants crossing the border.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration is seeking to clear potentially hundreds of thousands of deportation and asylum cases pending before immigration courts, an unprecedented move that could significantly reduce the current backlog of 1.7 million cases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Rwandan Court Declines to Extend Sentence for Paul Rusesabagina
description: Mr. Rusesabagina, who inspired the movie “Hotel Rwanda” and later lived in exile in the United States, had been given a 25-year term in a case condemned by human-rights groups.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — A court in Rwanda on Monday turned away an attempt by prosecutors to extend the 25-year sentence for Paul Rusesabagina, the hotelier turned dissident whose story was portrayed in the Oscar-nominated movie “Hotel Rwanda,” to life in prison.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: At the Grammys, the Young Succeed Most When They Seem Old
description: Despite nods to Gen Z, this year’s show favored history-minded performers like Silk Sonic, Jon Batiste, H.E.R. and Lady Gaga.
content: There is no surer way for a young musician to acquire a quick coat of gravitas than an appearance on the Grammy Awards. And there is no surer way for a young musician to speed the way to the Grammys than by already appearing to be old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: It’s Clearly South Carolina’s Time. Here’s How Dawn Staley Crafted It.
description: The South Carolina coach’s teams have proved themselves over and over, and the players have enough comfort together to play like “shorthand writing.”
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Dawn Staley was losing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Troy Closson
title: Mother of Slain 12-Year-Old Begs for Answers: ‘I’m Asking for Justice’
description: Kade Lewin was fatally shot on Thursday evening as he sat in a parked car with family members in Brooklyn. No arrests have been made.
content: The family of a 12-year-old boy who was fatally shot last week in Brooklyn pleaded for answers at a news conference with Mayor Eric Adams on Monday, describing deep pain and frustration that innocent victims continue to be caught up in gunfire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Tennessee Twist on Ham for Easter Brunch
description: The Nashville butcher shop Porter Road provides national shipping for its feast, which includes biscuits and pimento cheese.
content: Porter Road, a chef-owned butcher shop in Nashville that ships nationally, has assembled an Easter brunch package of ham and biscuits. (Just add eggs.) A half boneless ham — about 5.5 pounds of pasture-raised pork, cured, mildly smoked and ready for a slick of glaze for that Sunday centerpiece — will serve eight to 10. It comes with biscuits, both buttermilk and sharp Cheddar, and a tub of traditional Southern pimento cheese, all from Callie’s Hot Little Biscuit; $130, including shipping ($20 extra to some destinations). The company also sells half and whole hams without the accessories. Orders must be placed no later than April 11 for delivery by April 15.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Rosenthal
title: The End of the Covid Emergency Could Mean a Huge Loss of Health Insurance
description: Millions of Americans may lose their Medicaid coverage.
content: If there has been a silver lining to this terrible Covid-19 pandemic, it is that the rate of Americans without health insurance dropped to a near historic low, thanks to various federal initiatives connected to the government-declared public health emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Alexandra Alter
title: Book Banning Efforts Surged in 2021. These Titles Were the Most Targeted.
description: Most of the targeted books are about Black and L.G.B.T.Q. people, according to the American Library Association. The country’s polarized politics has fueled the rise.
content: Attempts to ban books in the United States surged in 2021 to the highest level since the American Library Association began tracking book challenges 20 years ago, the organization said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariq Panja
title: The Biennial World Cup May Be Dead, but FIFA’s Fight Isn’t Over
description: FIFA has quietly given up on a plan to hold the World Cup every two years. But surrender may not mean peace for its president, Gianni Infantino.
content: DOHA, Qatar — Gianni Infantino strode into the bright lights of a packed convention center alongside the emir of Qatar on Friday and declared that he expected this year’s World Cup to be the best ever. It was not an unusual boast; Infantino has made it before, in Russia in 2018, and he will surely make it again when the tournament heads to North America in 2026. But behind his beaming smile, and his bombastic words, the trip to the desert had been the setting for the FIFA president’s latest disappointment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lananh Nguyen
title: Wall Street’s Rigid Culture Bends to Demands for Flexibility at Work
description: Many big banks are offering flexible working arrangements — sometimes grudgingly — as they chase talent that would rather stay home.
content: When Tom Naratil arrived on Wall Street in the 1980s, work-life balance didn’t really exist. For most bankers of his generation, working long hours while missing out on family time wasn’t just necessary to get ahead, it was necessary to not be left behind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brad Plumer and Raymond Zhong
title: Stopping Climate Change Is Doable, but Time Is Short, U.N. Panel Warns
description: A major new scientific report offers a road map for how countries can limit global warming, but warns that the margin for error is vanishingly small.
content: Nations need to move away much faster from fossil fuels to retain any hope of preventing a perilous future on an overheated planet, according to a major new report on climate change released on Monday, although they have made some progress because of the falling costs of clean energy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Putin’s European allies
description: The fight between democracy and autocracy is happening not only in Ukraine.
content: President Biden has described the world as being engaged in a “battle between democracy and autocracy,” and Ukraine has become the central front.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Covid Proved That the C.D.C. Is Broken. Michael Lewis Has Ideas for How to Fix It.
description: The author of “The Premonition” discusses why America ditched its pandemic playbook.
content: Dr. Anthony Fauci has been the face of America’s Covid response and has been praised and vilified for his expertise. But who are all the other people who have worked behind the scenes at agencies like the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention to guide America through the pandemic? This is a question Michael Lewis tackles in his book “The Premonition,” which was published in May 2021. He talks about how getting to know these public health experts gave him a completely different understanding of the country’s public health system — and the systemic challenges institutions like the C.D.C. face when pandemics and other crises strike.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Option for Kosher Meat Delivered to Your Door
description: Prairie Street Prime offers glatt kosher meat for celebratory occasions like Passover.
content: Prairie Street Prime is a new delivery option for glatt kosher meat, like a hefty slab of brisket to braise for Passover (the first night is April 15), or for rib roast or tomahawk steak for a more spectacular presentation.  The company, based in Great Neck, N.Y, has been in development for several years. After some trial runs last year, it began shipping nationally this year. Some of the Star-K certified beef is U.S.D.A. Prime grade. The company’s founder, Elliot Moskowitz, a financier, saw that for kosher meat there was no equivalent to high-end companies like Snake River Farms or Pat LaFrieda selling directly to consumers. So he stepped in. The prime tomahawk steak ($130), once seared, then finished in a slow oven, was quite tender and had rich flavor. At around 40 ounces, it serves two to four. The choice grade tomahawk is $100. There are also short ribs, rib steaks and roasts, prime or choice, as well as lamb and veal. The meats are shipped frozen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Understand the Science of Sourdough
description: A detailed new book by the molecular biologist Karyn Lynn Newman offers lively insight.
content: Two years into the pandemic, and perhaps you still haven’t tackled sourdough? This highly detailed new book, “Sourdough by Science,” written with lively insight by Karyn Lynn Newman, a molecular biologist, might get you into fermentation after all. Dr. Newman clearly explains what goes on with sourdough starter. Though she gives instructions for developing your own, she recommends buying it for reliability. Different flours, salt, proportions and equipment, as well as the steps that ensure successful dough-making, are covered. And there are recipes, including options you might not associate with sourdough, like focaccia. What if your crust is not shiny? Is the flavor too sour? She troubleshoots as well.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Astor
title: Lygia Fagundes Telles, Popular Brazilian Novelist, Dies at 98
description: One of her country’s first writers to address female sexuality from a woman’s perspective, she produced four novels and dozens of short stories that could be read as political allegories.
content: Lygia Fagundes Telles, one of Brazil’s most popular writers, whose stories of women trapped in unsatisfying relationships could also be read as allegories of her country’s political situation, died on Sunday at her home in São Paulo. She was 98.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: A Century of the BBC, a ‘Quasi-Mystical’ Part of England’s Psyche
description: David Hendy’s “The BBC” looks back at 100 years of wartime reporting, dramas, satires and weather reports.
content: The British Broadcasting Corporation, the BBC — the Beeb — turns 100 this year. “Hullo, hullo, 2LO calling, 2LO calling,” a few thousand listeners heard through the hissing ether at 6 p.m. on Nov. 14, 1922. “This is the British Broadcasting Company. 2LO. Stand by for one minute please!” What followed were short news and weather bulletins, read twice, the second time slowly so that listeners could take notes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: ‘Your Wife Seems to Care About the Rose Bushes’
description: Readers weigh in.
content: In the seven months since I began this newsletter, I’ve received thousands of emails from readers. These have led to some in-depth correspondences with all sorts of people who have pushed my thinking in meaningful ways. Today I want to thank everyone who has written in and respond to some emails publicly, which I’ll try to do somewhat regularly. I have always envisioned this newsletter as a dialogue between you and me, so if you have any concerns or thoughts or even just endless praise, please write to me at kang-newsletter@nytimes.com.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Barnard
title: The Prosecutors Who Are Heading For the Door
description: In every borough, the lawyers in district attorneys’ offices are leaving because of burnout, rising workload and modest salaries.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. Today we’ll find out why prosecutors are leaving the New York City district attorneys’ offices in droves. We’ll also look at the techniques other cities are using to persuade homeless people to leave the subways.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: How the Recoil From Russian Gas Is Scrambling World Markets
description: Europe wants 50 billion cubic meters of additional natural gas, but supplies are tight. Prices will rise, and other regions might have to do with less.
content: Just months ago, Germany’s plans to build a terminal for receiving shiploads of liquefied natural gas were in disarray. Would-be developers were not convinced customers would make enough use of a facility that can cost billions of dollars. And concerns about climate change undermined the future of a fossil fuel like natural gas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nancy Wartik and Jonathan Wolfe
title: Covid’s Toll on Diabetic Americans
description: After older people and nursing home residents, no other group seems to have been hit harder.
content: After older people and nursing home residents, no other group seems to have been hit harder by Covid than people with diabetes. They account for a staggering 30 to 40 percent of all U.S. Covid deaths, several studies suggest.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: New Mezcals With a ‘Mad’ Backstory
description: Fósforo, a new mezcal brand financed by Jim Cramer, is releasing two styles of the spirit made from tobalá.
content: A new mezcal, Fósforo, will add two spirits to the crowded mezcal market, with sales beginning online on Monday and on shelves April 18. Both are distilled from the tobalá varietal of the agave plant, a species little known to Americans until recently and which has become increasingly popular among mezcal fans. Behind the spirits is Aarón Alva Sánchez, a fourth-generation mezcalero (mezcal maker) in Huehuetlán el Grande, Puebla, who has spent 20 years taming tobalá, an agave plant with a reputation for being difficult to cultivate. In a twist, Fósforo is backed not by an actor or musician (as is common in the world of celebrity tequilas and mezcals), but by Jim Cramer of “Mad Money” fame and his wife, Lisa Detwiler. Fósforo’s two offerings are the fruity and grassy Tobalá, and the ashy and vegetal Tobalá Penca, which is aged for one to three months in glass carboys with a cooked agave leaf.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: A Flight Over China in Clear Skies, Followed by a Nosedive
description: Investigators face a formidable challenge in figuring out why China Eastern Flight 5735 crashed on March 21.
content: BEIJING — China Eastern Airlines Flight 5735 was at 29,100 feet in clear afternoon skies over the hills of southern China, seemingly ready for a smooth landing in Guangzhou. The plane, a Boeing 737-800 NG, was only seven years old. One of China’s most experienced aviators was among the three pilots in the cockpit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: The Fallout from Bucha
description: President Biden called the atrocity a “war crime.”
content: President Biden called the indiscriminate civilian deaths in Bucha a “war crime” and said the U.S. would impose additional sanctions on Russia. Some European leaders also demanded tougher sanctions, including a total ban on Russian fuel imports. Here are the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Shopping for Pot Racks
description: If you cook a lot, you know how useful they are. And if you don’t know how to cook? An impressive pot rack will make guests think you do.
content: Whether you’re short on cabinet space, or you like the look of a professional chef’s kitchen or you just want to show off your cookware collection, pot racks and rails are the answer: They not only keep your skillets and saucepans handy, but they also double as decoration for the kitchen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Sherman
title: ‘Downstate’ and ‘Catch as Catch Can’ in Playwrights Horizons New Season
description: The company has announced five works for its 2022-23 lineup, which will include Agnes Borinsky’s “The Trees,” directed by Tina Satter.
content: “Downstate,” a Bruce Norris play that The New York Times’s chief theater critic, Jesse Green, has called a “squirmy moral-thrill-ride,” will make its New York premiere in October as part of Playwrights Horizons’s new season, the company announced on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Maslin Nir
title: ‘Dating Coach’ Charged in Capitol Riot Gets Prison Term for Gun Crime
description: Samuel Fisher, who as Brad Holiday traded in conspiracy theories and misogyny online, still faces federal charges related to Jan. 6.
content: A self styled dating coach who prosecutors say participated in the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol was sentenced to three and a half years in prison after he pleaded guilty to a gun possession charge in Manhattan Supreme Court on Monday — a case that emerged through a search warrant related to his apparent involvement in the riot.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Has the Pandemic Changed Your Mental Health?
description: Many of us are trying to adapt to the new normal with emotional and mental scars that didn’t exist before the pandemic.
content: After more than two years of illness, upheaval and loss, many of us are being asked to return to something resembling our prepandemic lives. Offices are filling up, masks are coming off and more governments and organizations are making plans to “live with” the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Machine Gun Kelly Has a Second No. 1 Album, ‘Mainstream Sellout’
description: The pop-punk musician’s latest release had the equivalent of 93,000 sales in the United States.
content: Machine Gun Kelly, the onetime rapper who has remade himself into the jester prince of a new wave of pop-punk, opens at No. 1 on the Billboard chart with his latest album, “Mainstream Sellout.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley
title: Bristling Against the West, China Rallies Domestic Sympathy for Russia
description: China’s Communist Party is mounting an ideological campaign aimed at officials and students. The message: The country will not turn its back on Russia.
content: While Russian troops have battered Ukraine, officials in China have been meeting behind closed doors to study a Communist Party-produced documentary that extols President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as a hero.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sandra E. Garcia
title: Julian Gaines Has a Question: ‘How Do I Paint Oregon Black?’
description: A love for Nike led him away from his home in Chicagoland to a grand artist’s studio on a weed farm outside Portland.
content: In a cavernous studio on a weed farm in Forest Grove, Ore., about halfway between Portland and the Tillamook State Forest, Julian Gaines, an artist born and raised in Chicagoland, is creating a body of work devoted to Black American life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melonyce McAfee
title: What’s the Best Advice You’ve Received About Motherhood?
description: Your response may be used in an upcoming story.
content: Mothers can get lots of unsolicited advice, starting even before a child is born: “Don’t eat that, you might harm the baby!” “Sleep on your side, you don’t want to cramp the little one!” And once the kid arrives, all bets are off. From feeding an infant to disciplining an unruly teen, people seem to think it’s all up for discussion.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: What to Know About the Sacramento Shooting
description: At least six people were killed and 12 wounded on Sunday in a killing that the police say involved multiple shooters.
content: Six people were killed and at least a dozen wounded in downtown Sacramento on Sunday in what the authorities say is the largest mass shooting in the city’s history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.
content: This house is in a mostly residential section of Altadena, about a five-minute drive from the shopping along Lake Avenue. A number of trailheads are within a short drive or walk, including Henninger Trailhead, which has paths of varying difficulty for hikers and mountain bikers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: Some easyJet flights are canceled after workers test positive, and other developments.
description: The low-cost British airline easyJet canceled dozens of flights on Monday because of  “higher than usual levels of employee sickness” from BA. 2, the Omicron subvariant that is spreading in Europe.
content: The low-cost British airline easyJet canceled dozens of flights on Monday because of  “higher than usual levels of employee sickness” from BA. 2, the Omicron subvariant that is spreading in Europe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachelle Bonja, Diana Nguyen, Mooj Zadie, Rachel Quester, Paige Cowett, Liz O. Baylen and Chris Wood
title: ‘The Illegality of the Plan Was Obvious’
description: A judge has ruled that Donald J. Trump most likely committed a crime in trying to stop the certification of the 2020 election.
content: After months of investigation by a congressional committee, a federal judge has found that President Donald J. Trump and his allies most likely engaged in illegal activity in the wake of the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford and Stellantis say car sales fell at the start of the year.
description: The automakers’ performance in the first three months was in line with that of other companies, like General Motors and Toyota.
content: Ford Motor said on Monday that its new-vehicle sales in the United States fell 17 percent in the first three months of the year, in line with other automakers that are struggling to keep their factories running amid a global shortage of computer chips.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Which ‘Radioactive Republicans’ Are We Betting On?
description: It’s sort of amazing how consistent our former president is in gravitating to the worst politicians imaginable.
content: Gail Collins: Bret, let’s relax and talk about long-term goals that we totally do not share. For instance, how would you feel about raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Miller
title: Terry Francona Is Back and Feeling Feisty
description: Francona missed huge chunks of two seasons with health issues, and the Cleveland Guardians are thrilled to have their merry prankster of a manager back in the clubhouse.
content: GOODYEAR, Ariz. — Terry Francona is healthy again. You can see it in Mike Barnett’s hair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Holy Cross is renaming its science complex for Fauci.
description: The move, announced Monday, will coincide with Dr. Anthony S. Fauci’s 60th reunion at the college’s campus in Worcester, Mass., in June.
content: The College of the Holy Cross is renaming the science buildings on its campus in Worcester, Mass., in honor of one of its most famous graduates, Dr. Anthony S. Fauci.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: Gene Shue, All-Star and Longtime N.B.A. Coach, Dies at 90
description: He had a seven-decade pro career, starting as a guard with the Pistons before coaching for 22 years, leading the Bullets and the 76ers to the finals.
content: Gene Shue, an All-Star N.B.A. guard of the late 1950s and early ’60s who went on to turn losers into winners in 22 seasons as a pro coach, died Sunday at his home in Marina del Rey, Calif. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum and Julia Jacobs
title: Volodymyr Zelensky speaks to Grammys audience in a prerecorded video.
description: The Ukrainian president, Volodymyr Zelensky, made a plea for support before John Legend performed, sharing the stage with a poet and a singer from Ukraine.
content: Volodymyr Zelensky, the president of Ukraine, addressed the Grammy Awards in a video, giving an emotional plea for support in his country’s war against Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold and Erin Woo
title: What Other Cities Can Teach New York About Homelessness on Transit
description: As New York City makes a new push to relocate homeless people from the subway, the experiences of Philadelphia, San Francisco and others show the challenges ahead.
content: Days before New York City’s mayor unveiled a plan in February to address the issue of homeless people sheltering on the subway, three police officers in San Francisco were hustling a homeless woman up a staircase at the Civic Center transit station.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Judge Keeps New York’s New Electoral Map Intact for Now
description: The stay by an appellate judge puts on hold a lower-court ruling that New York’s newly drawn congressional and legislative districts were unconstitutional.
content: A New York appellate judge on Monday hit the brakes on a sweeping lower-court decision that invalidated newly drawn legislative districts favorable to Democrats and threatened to throw the state’s election season into turmoil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Rules Against Police in Malicious Prosecution Case
description: Plaintiffs need show only that the charges against them were dropped, the majority said, to satisfy a requirement that they had obtained a “favorable termination” of the prosecution.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court ruled on Monday in favor of a Brooklyn man who said he had been falsely accused by police officers of resisting arrest, saying he could sue for malicious prosecution under a federal civil rights law.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Blinder
title: South Carolina, a Dominant Force All Season, Delivers a Championship Over UConn
description: And it made its final victory over the Huskies — the 11-time champions — look easy.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — It was a 40-minute championship game, yes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
title: With Each New Crisis in Hong Kong, Pressure Built on a Beijing Loyalist
description: Carrie Lam, the territory’s chief executive, said Monday that she would not seek a second term. Her tenure was marked by protests, a contentious law and a devastating Covid outbreak.
content: HONG KONG — Under the watch of Carrie Lam, Hong Kong’s chief executive, huge citywide protests deepened political divisions. A national security law silenced a once-vibrant civil society. And restrictive pandemic policies threatened Hong Kong’s status as Asia’s world city.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: The Ruble Has Bounced Back. What Does That Mean?
description: Russia’s financial position is stronger in the short term than many expected.
content: President Biden bragged on Twitter on March 26 that “as a result of our unprecedented sanctions, the ruble was almost immediately reduced to rubble.” It was an ill-timed tweet. The Russian currency did crash in February after sanctions were imposed, but by the time Biden exulted, it had already regained lost ground. It’s now worth about 1.2 cents, which is down from 1.3 cents before the war but well above its wartime low of less than 0.8 cents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Matina Stevis-Gridneff
title: Images of Russian Atrocities Push West Toward Tougher Sanctions
description: President Biden called for Vladimir Putin to face trial for war crimes, and European officials will meet to consider possibly banning some Russian energy imports.
content: The images of dead Ukrainians, some with their hands tied and others haphazardly buried in pits, spurred shocked Western leaders on Monday to promise even tougher sanctions against Russia, including possibly on energy, as the Kremlin dug in and showed signs of preparing a new assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Still Going, Even as the Glory Fades
description: Mike Montgomery once threw a “golden pitch” in a World Series, but at 32 he is in minor league camp for the Mets hoping for one more chance for things to click.
content: PORT ST. LUCIE, Fla. — He started to believe in a curse. Then he trusted in a different kind of destiny. Baseball has a way of toying with emotions. Ask Mike Montgomery.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: Why the Grammys Couldn’t Resist Jon Batiste
description: The jazz pianist is an inheritor more than an innovator, but he puts the past to use in service of fun, blending genres and embodying the pleasures of his hometown, New Orleans.
content: Accepting the Grammy for album of the year on Sunday night, Jon Batiste delivered a minute-and-a-half manifesto that belied his roots in the musical culture of New Orleans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Debra Kamin
title: You Want Your Child Vaccinated, but Your Ex Says No
description: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
content: In late 2021, Adele Grote, a divorced mother of two in Minneapolis, took her children to a vaccination clinic at the Mall of America. But when her 13-year-old daughter called her father to let him know they were getting the shot, Ms. Grote knew they would have to leave without it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Wang and Joy Dong
title: China deploys 2,000 military medics and 10,000 medical workers to Shanghai.
description: More than 2,000 military medics and 10,000 medical workers from around China have been deployed to Shanghai in recent days to help tame the city’s coronavirus outbreak — a potential sign of the central Chinese government’s concern that cases there have spiraled out of local officials’ control.
content: More than 2,000 military medics and 10,000 medical workers from around China have been deployed to Shanghai in recent days to help tame the city’s coronavirus outbreak — a potential sign of the central Chinese government’s concern that cases there have spiraled out of local officials’ control.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Is UConn’s Dynasty Done? Auriemma Likes the Outlook for Next Year.
description: The Huskies, winners of 11 national championships, have gone without a title since 2016.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — Connecticut has spent almost three decades as the most formidable threat in women’s college basketball, dangerous even when not ranked No. 1 in Division I for weeks at a time — which is where the Huskies spent a significant portion of that time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Spencer
title: Cole Sprouse on Finding a Healthy Balance in Hollywood
description: The former child actor wanted to leave showbiz. Now, the “Moonshot” and “Riverdale” star is finding he can act and tend his photography career as well.
content: “I hope you don’t mind, I’m going to be scarfing down this chicken wrap at the same time we talk,” Cole Sprouse politely informs me as he sits in the kitchen wearing a fuzzy, baby blue sweater. The wrap in question is already halfway to his mouth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Simonson
title: The Cocktail Bar Dead Rabbit Will Expand to New Orleans and Beyond
description: New locations of the Lower Manhattan bar are in the works, and a sister bar, Hazel and Apple, will open in Charleston, S.C., this year.
content: The Dead Rabbit is multiplying. The cocktail bar and pub in Lower Manhattan has plans to open new branches in New Orleans and Austin, Texas, in 2023, with hopes to open other locations in the next five years. A sister bar, called Hazel and Apple, will open in Charleston, S.C., later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: A Challenger Emerges in the National League
description: The Mets went on a huge off-season spending spree, and they are willing to spend even more. The Dodgers are proof that the approach doesn’t always work.
content: In the San Francisco Giants and the Los Angeles Dodgers, the National League West had the two best teams in the majors during the 2021 regular season. But after winning the N.L. East (again), the scrappy Atlanta Braves knocked off the Dodgers in the National League Championship Series and then upset the Houston Astros in the World Series. While hoping for a repeat, Atlanta faces a daunting challenge in the form of Steven A. Cohen’s massive bank account, as the Mets’ owner seems determined to spend whatever it takes to get his childhood favorite team its first title since 1986.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: These Colorful Chocolate Easter Eggs Dazzle
description: A beautiful set of treats, with fillings like coffee cream, mango and more, from Norman Love Confections is sure to  delight.
content: Chocolate Easter eggs, half-eggs really, are having their Jackson Pollock moment this year at Norman Love Confections in Fort Myers, Fla. Mr. Love covers the dark, milk and white chocolate shells in ombré pastels with contrasting spatters. Inside are opulent fillings like caramel, coconut cream, coffee cream, peanut butter, raspberry and mango for a two-bite treat. There are 10 varieties, $26 for the box. An assortment of the  eggs and other chocolates, 25 pieces, is $55.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Delayed by Virus, Grammy Awards Celebrate Music Industry’s Return
description: Jon Batiste won album of the year, Silk Sonic song and record of the year and Olivia Rodrigo best new artist at a ceremony where President Zelensky of Ukraine made an appeal for help.
content: The 64th annual Grammy Awards on Sunday night featured major wins by Silk Sonic, Jon Batiste and Olivia Rodrigo, elaborate performances from a music industry struggling to emerge from the pandemic and an impassioned plea for help from President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lyn Woodward
title: Women Drive Off-Road in Saudi Desert for Fun and Bragging Rights
description: Just years after women could legally drive there, the Rally Jameel celebrates a new first.
content: HAIL, Saudi Arabia — The starting line for the Rally Jameel was drawn in 2017, when women in Saudi Arabia earned the right to a driver’s license. Last month, the ceremonial green flag finally fell on the kingdom’s first all-women rally at Qishlah Palace in Hail, waved by Prince Abdulaziz bin Saad bin Abdulaziz, and Saudi Arabia marked another historic beginning for women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: Four Days That Changed Golf
description: Tiger Woods was not supposed to win the 1997 Masters, but when he did, by 12 strokes — one of 20 Masters records he set in that tournament — he remade the game and catapulted himself to stardom.
content: Perhaps the most important thing to remember on the 25th anniversary of Tiger Woods’s seismic victory at the 1997 Masters, the first of his 15 major championships, is that almost no one saw it coming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: The Problem of ‘Personal Precedents’ of Supreme Court Justices
description: Their efforts to seem consistent can clash with respect for precedent in the usual sense. But a new article argues that personal precedents have a role to play as legal building blocks.
content: WASHINGTON — Supreme Court justices, like most people, like to appear to be consistent. No one wants to be thought to be a flip-flopper, an opportunist or a hypocrite.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Sneed
title: Rex Chapman Isn’t Sure He Deserves Good Things
description: With 1.2 million Twitter followers and a new show debuting Monday, the former N.B.A. player appears to have an enviable life. But he’s haunted by what happened the last time he was famous.
content: Sitting in a Midtown Manhattan cafe after shooting B-roll for his new show on CNN+, Rex Chapman says he knows that he’s living a dream, and it’s making him uncomfortable. “I struggle with it,” he said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Higgins
title: With a Neutral Stance on Ukraine, Viktor Orban Pulled in Voters
description: The Hungarian prime minister’s party also made a strong showing in Sunday’s election, though independent observers said the vote was tilted in the ruling party’s favor.
content: BUDAPEST — Savoring the election victory of a rare European leader who has not condemned him as a war criminal, President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia on Monday congratulated Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary for winning a fourth term and said he looked forward to an expansion of “partnership ties.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Gov. Larry Hogan Approves New Maryland Congressional Map
description: Drawn by Democrats and approved by a Republican governor, the new map will most likely result in a similar delegation to the state’s current one.
content: Gov. Larry Hogan of Maryland on Monday signed into law a new congressional map drawn by Democrats, a little more than a week after a judge called their previous effort an “extreme gerrymander” and threw it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gabe Cohn
title: What’s on TV This Week: A Pair of New Docs, and ‘Killing Eve’
description: Major documentaries about Benjamin Franklin and Tony Hawk are on PBS and HBO. And “Killing Eve” airs its final episode.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, April 4-10. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Jennifer Venditti Will See You Now
description: The casting director behind “Euphoria” and “Uncut Gems” puts real life onto big and small screens. A new book details her process.
content: When Jennifer Venditti was a child growing up in Saint Paul, Minn., in the days before cellphones, her parents would sometimes deposit her with a babysitter for the night, leaving a contact number for where they’d be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin and Lauren Hirsch
title: Starbucks’s new C.E.O. scraps stock buybacks to ‘invest more profit into our people.’
description: On his first day back in the top job, Howard Schultz made an abrupt change in policy at the company as it faces rising worker discontent.
content: As Starbucks faces a rising wave of employee unrest, its new chief executive is abruptly shifting how the coffee chain splits its profits between workers and shareholders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anushka Patil
title: U.S. colleges that once championed surveillance virus testing are backing away.
description: Institutions that used to test everyone on campus regularly now say it’s enough just to test the unvaccinated and people with symptoms.
content: Colleges and universities across the United States have relaxed campus requirements for coronavirus testing of vaccinated people in recent weeks, chipping away at some of the last widespread surveillance testing programs and dismaying public health experts, who say that robust sources of transmission data will be lost.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Callie Holtermann
title: Who Was Your Favorite Musical Artist This Year?
description: Were any of your top songs, albums or artists recognized at the Grammy Awards?
content: At the Grammy Awards on Sunday, Olivia Rodrigo, Silk Sonic and Jon Batiste took home some of the top prizes during what New York Times critic Jon Caramanica called “an utterly inconsistent night.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Rifkin
title: Tommy Davis, Batting Star With the ’60s Dodgers, Dies at 83
description: A two-time batting champion, he helped power a dominant Los Angeles team, but a serious injury derailed his career, and he fell short of the Hall of Fame.
content: Tommy Davis, a former Brooklyn-born baseball prodigy who became a two-time All-Star, won two consecutive National League batting titles and led the star-studded Los Angeles Dodgers to a World Series championship in 1963, died on Sunday in Phoenix. He was 83.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Schwartz
title: I’m a Scientist in California. Here’s What Worries Me Most About Drought.
description: Our tools for managing water in the West are growing more inaccurate.
content: Outside my lab near Donner Pass in the Sierra Nevada of California, new animal tracks are on the snow after a winter of hibernation, bird songs are lofting through the air, and the creek is flowing strongly with water from the melting snow. Spring has come worryingly early to the Sierra Nevada.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: Anne Parsons, Who Revived the Detroit Symphony, Dies at 64
description: She shepherded the orchestra through a bitter six-month strike and then worked to ensure that it flourished after what many considered a near-death moment.
content: Anne Parsons, who as president and chief executive revitalized the Detroit Symphony Orchestra in the aftermath of a bitter strike, using education and technology to attract new audiences, died on March 28 in Detroit. She was 64.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malachy Browne, David Botti and Haley Willis
title: Satellite images show bodies lay in Bucha for weeks, despite Russian claims.
description: The images rebut Russia’s claim that the killing of civilians in Bucha, near Kyiv, took place after its soldiers had left town.
content: An analysis of satellite images by The New York Times rebuts claims by Russia that the killing of civilians in Bucha, a suburb of Kyiv, occurred after its soldiers had left the town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Søren Solkær
title: Gazing at the ‘Black Sun’: The Transfixing Beauty of Starling Murmurations
description: Each spring and autumn, the skies in southern Denmark come to life with the swirling displays of hundreds of thousands of starlings, an event known locally as “sort sol.”
content: It was a late February evening in 2020, and I was standing in the marshlands of Friesland, a northern province in the Netherlands. Above my head, hundreds of thousands of starlings were swirling, swooping and diving in a dramatic fashion, blackening the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Steven Erlanger
title: Zelensky blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for denying Ukraine NATO membership.
description: In a video address, he said that NATO’s decision in 2008 not to give Ukraine a path to membership helped lead to atrocities by Russian forces.
content: BRUSSELS — President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine lambasted the former leaders of Germany and France, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy, in a video address released late on Sunday, seemingly blaming them for the deaths of Ukrainian civilians.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: A Small Earthquake on Staten Island
description: Why a pro-union vote at Amazon may be a big deal.
content: I grew up in a relatively equal society, at least as far as incomes were concerned. Obviously there were class differences in 1974, the year I graduated from college; some jobs paid much better than others, some people were rich while others were desperately poor. But for most Americans these differences were much narrower than they are today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane, Alexandra E. Petri and Aina J. Khan
title: Senate negotiators announce a deal on a smaller Covid spending proposal without global vaccine funding.
description: The $10 billion package does not include funds for the global vaccination effort, frustrating some Democrats.
content: Senators announced a deal on a $10 billion coronavirus aid package on Monday to provide additional aid for domestic testing, vaccination and treatment efforts, after dropping a push to include billions for the global vaccination effort.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: ‘Balkan Bordello’ Review: A Tragic Tale Reborn for a Time of War
description: In this international production, you can check into the Balkan Express Motel, if you dare, and fulfill an ancient generational curse.
content: To Orestes, the discord between his parents is part of “the family dysfunction.” That’s true as far as it goes, but it does gloss over some gruesome details: his military commander father, Agamemnon, sacrificing Orestes’s sister, Iphigenia; and his mother, Clytemnestra, avenging her favorite child’s death by killing Agamemnon when he returns home from war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: A Private War: Why PTSD Is Still Overlooked
description: Experts say millions of people are affected by trauma, which has become a buzzword and a meme. So why aren’t more of them being treated?
content: Nancy Méndez-Booth was diagnosed with PTSD after she delivered a stillborn baby in the winter of 2008. Within an hour after she rushed to the hospital, in labor and exhilarated, a doctor told her that the baby she had spent years planning for had no heartbeat.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: TikTok to the Grammys: How a ‘Bridgerton’ Musical Beat Broadway
description: With their award for “The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical,” two musical theater newcomers won against veterans like Andrew Lloyd Webber and Stephen Schwartz.
content: When the lyricist-composer duo behind “The Unofficial Bridgerton Musical” stepped onstage Sunday to accept their Grammy for best musical theater album, the list of people they wanted to thank did not start with a record label or producer, but with their social media followers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: She Moved From the Chem Lab to the Kitchen, but Not by Choice
description: In Bonnie Garmus’s debut novel, “Lessons in Chemistry,” a woman who has been banished to the home front turns it into a staging ground for a revolution.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: The Horror in Bucha
description: Mounting evidence of atrocities is spurring calls to hold Russia accountable.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: French Election Opens Up as Marine Le Pen Surges
description: President Emmanuel Macron’s belated entry into the campaign and his focus on Ukraine have left him vulnerable to a strong challenge from the right.
content: PARIS — At last, Emmanuel Macron stepped forth. The French president entered a vast arena this weekend, plunged into darkness and lit only by spotlights and glow sticks, before a crowd of 30,000 supporters in a domed stadium in the Paris suburbs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Hoffman
title: American League Has an East Coast Bias
description: The A.L. West has high-priced superstars. The A.L. Central has intriguing story lines. But the mighty A.L. East has four teams capable of winning 100 games.
content: After the dust of the off-season settled, the American League had a huge shuffling of stars. But the power still resides largely in the stacked East, where four teams topped 90 wins last year. With Houston weakened by the loss of Carlos Correa and the teams in the West having various holes, the East could be even more dominant this season.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Licensed to Drive, and Now Going Off-Road
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, April 4, 2022.
content: “My mother told me I am a daughter of the desert. Now I just want to drive rally as much as I can.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 11: I Like Mike
description: Prince’s grand plan is revealed. Chuck is less than impressed.
content: “Michael [expletive] Prince is running for president.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff and Tyler Hicks
title: The War Moves East, as Putin Looks for a Victory
description: Having failed to score a quick triumph, Russia is shifting its attention to the contested breakaway enclaves, in Ukraine’s East. It is also shelling large cities to keep enemy forces from the expected new areas of battle.
content: KHARKIV, Ukraine — Soldiers waved off traffic, emerging from trenches dug into the side of a multistory apartment building, telling motorists to turn around. Firefighters arrived soon after, unfurling hoses to combat a growing blaze ignited by an artillery round that hit a nearby housing complex.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Atrocities in Bucha could complicate Russia-Ukraine talks.
description: It was unclear what effect the killing of civilians outside Kyiv, the Ukrainian capital, would have on negotiations.
content: Russian and Ukrainian negotiators have been holding intermittent peace talks since a few days after the war began, but it has not been clear that they would amount to anything — or that the Kremlin was serious about negotiating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch
title: Elon Musk becomes Twitter’s largest shareholder.
description: The Tesla chief executive, who has been critical of Twitter’s content moderation policies, has bought 9.2 percent of the social media company.
content: When Elon Musk mulled taking Tesla private in 2018, he posted on Twitter to tell the world about it. When he got stuck in traffic in 2016, he tweeted the idea of an underground tunnel system to alleviate “soul destroying” congestion. And when he challenged President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to one-on-one combat last month, he broadcast it on Twitter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Asian Americans Grapple With Tide of Attacks’
description: In this lesson, students will learn about what Asian American leaders believe should happen in the wake of recent attacks. Then, they will consider what they can to do to prevent hate crimes.
content: Featured Article: “Asian Americans Grapple With Tide of Attacks: ‘We Need Our Safety Back’” by Jeffery C. Mays, Dana Rubinstein and Grace Ashford
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Barachou Expands Its Offerings
description: The Upper West Side store has opened a second location in the West Village with more kitchen space and more to offer.
content: Barachou, Rebecca Tison’s Upper West Side pastry shop, opened in 2019 and specializes in a kaleidoscope of cream puffs and other French pastries. She found a steady clientele, which allowed her to open a second location. It’s in the West Village and seems to attract a stream of shoppers and snackers for coffee and pastries at cafe tables. She has more kitchen space downtown and has expanded her repertory to include individual pastries and tarts, with more savory options like croissants and olive and Cheddar bread. More complex pastries, like Paris-Brest, and a thick French custard flan are also new.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: April 4, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, April 4, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: New Era of Deals for College Players Means Business Considerations, Like Taxes
description: The April 18 tax deadline is coming. College basketball players have been busy with the N.C.A.A. tournaments. Some factored that into their endorsement deals.
content: NEW ORLEANS — Trevor Keels’s timing was impeccable. The Duke freshman scored 25 points in his first college game, a nationally televised triumph over Kentucky at the self-proclaimed mecca of college basketball, Madison Square Garden. He could not have picked a bigger stage — or a better time — to announce himself to the college basketball world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Glass Animals miss ceremony after lead singer tests positive for Covid-19.
description: The band’s song, “Heat Waves,” is currently the No. 1 song in the country.
content: The lead singer of the British alternative-pop band Glass Animals — a nominee for best new artist — tested positive for the coronavirus, and all of its members have decided to not attend the awards show, the group said in an Instagram post on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Tiffany May
title: Carrie Lam, racked by Covid failures, won’t seek a new term to lead Hong Kong.
description: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, announced on Monday that she would not seek a second term, after a huge surge in coronavirus infections left the global financial hub with one of the highest virus death rates in the world.
content: HONG KONG — Carrie Lam, the chief executive of Hong Kong, announced on Monday that she would not seek a second term, after a huge surge in coronavirus infections left the global financial hub with one of the highest virus death rates in the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amal El-Mohtar
title: Ordinary People, Extraordinary Circumstances
description: These new science fiction and fantasy novels feature Icelandic horses, memory removal and romance in the multiverse.
content: To paraphrase Ian Fleming: To read one good book is happenstance; two is coincidence; three is wild good fortune. That a columnist should enjoy novels in her purview is not particularly noteworthy — but to read three excellent books in sequence, all for the same column, is unusual, a critic’s jackpot. These are stories of ordinary people in extraordinary circumstances, and the less you know about their plots going in, the better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Here’s how Russia has avoided defaulting on its debt.
description: But analysts question whether sanctions will eventually affect Russia’s ability to pay.
content: Despite strict economic sanctions, shrinking currency reserves and nervous banks, Russia has kept up with payments for government debt, confounding expectations from just a few weeks ago, when the ratings agencies believed a default was imminent and the government said it might repay its international loans in rubles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Kids Are Right About Email, Too
description: It is now just a way to be at the beck and call of anyone, and any robot, with an internet connection.
content: NASHVILLE — My great-grandfather, whom the family called Papa Doc, was a country doctor who practiced medicine by examining sick people in their own homes and delivering babies in their parents’ own beds. For that reason, Papa Doc’s house, though modest even by Lower Alabama standards, was one of the first in the county to have a telephone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: Taiwan relaxes its quarantine measures even as it confronts an outbreak.
description: Taiwan has thrived as a bubble of normalcy through most of the pandemic. But now, as it faces a growing coronavirus outbreak, the island’s health authorities have relaxed several preventive measures to ease pressure on medical resources for the long battle against the virus.
content: Taiwan has thrived as a bubble of normalcy through most of the pandemic. But now, as it faces a growing coronavirus outbreak, the island’s health authorities have relaxed several preventive measures to ease pressure on medical resources for the long battle against the virus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Skandha Gunasekara and Emily Schmall
title: Sri Lanka Protesters Defy President, Rejecting a Cabinet Shuffle
description: The country’s Rajapaksa dynasty is facing its toughest challenge yet as protesters demand that the president step down amid a devastating economic crisis.
content: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka — After weeks of upheaval over Sri Lanka’s economic crisis and growing resentment to his rule, President Gotabaya Rajapaksa offered the public a sacrifice, urging almost his entire cabinet, including several family members, to resign en masse while promising reform.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andy Furillo, Emma Goldberg and Thomas Fuller
title: A Landscaper, an Aspiring Social Worker: Lives Cut Short in Sacramento Shooting
description: It was still unclear on Monday who was behind the gunfire that left six dead and 12 wounded in California’s capital early Sunday.
content: SACRAMENTO — The six people killed in an eruption of gunfire in downtown Sacramento over the weekend, one of the worst mass killings in the city’s history, ranged in age from 21 to 57, the county coroner’s office said Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josef Joffe
title: World War II, Ukraine and the Future of Conflict
description: Richard Overy’s prodigious “Blood and Ruins” is a sweeping history of World War II packed with lessons for the future.
content: “Books have their own fates,” the Romans taught. Running for just under a thousand small-print pages, “Blood and Ruins,” too, has had its own fate. After 40 years of painstaking scholarly effort, Richard Overy was overridden by Vladimir Putin. Russia’s murderous assault on Ukraine makes the subtitle, “The Last Imperial War, 1931-1945,” ring premature. After 77 years of relative peace in Europe, the longest ever, conquest and slaughter are back. So are sorrow and pity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Goldstein
title: U.S. government to jury in 1MDB trial: Convict even if you don’t believe our star witness.
description: The defense said the only evidence of involvement by Roger Ng, who is accused of receiving illegal kickbacks, was the testimony of Tim Leissner, a former Goldman partner who admitted on the stand to lying a lot.
content: A federal prosecutor told jurors on Monday that they had received enough evidence to convict a former Goldman Sachs banker for his role in one of the biggest international money laundering and bribery schemes even without the testimony of the government’s star witness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: The Grammys pays tribute to Taylor Hawkins, Stephen Sondheim and other music luminaries.
description: The Foo Fighters drummer was honored alongside Charlie Watts, DMX and Meat Loaf, among others.
content: The Grammy Awards took an extended moment to honor Taylor Hawkins, the Foo Fighters drummer who died just over a week ago while on tour with the band in Colombia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: Grammys Red Carpet: Show Girls, Tiger Queens and Pearly Kings
description: The Vegas evening was an exuberant reminder of why red carpets can be fun for both stars and fans.
content: Ah, Las Vegas: It provides inspiration in so many ways. That’s how it seemed, anyway, judging from the Grammy red carpet, newly located to the MGM Grand Garden Arena in the city of … gosh, so many things! Sin and lights and camp and Elvis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: On the Scene: At a Far Right Rally in France
description: I went to a rally held by Marine Le Pen, the far-right French presidential candidate who is rising in the polls.
content: I went to a rally held by Marine Le Pen, the far-right French presidential candidate who is rising in the polls.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Victor
title: How to Avoid Sharing Misinformation on Ukraine
description: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.
content: Uncritically sharing posts about Ukraine can make you an accidental conduit for war propaganda. Here's what to watch for.
source.name: The New York Times

author: Compiled by John Otis
title: How Much Do You Know About Bosnia and Herzegovina?
description: Can you find Bosnia and Herzegovina on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with three million people?
content: Can you find Bosnia and Herzegovina on a map? What else do you know about this Southeastern European nation with three million people?
source.name: The New York Times

title: What You Get for $3 Million in California
description: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.
content: A Spanish-style house in Altadena, a converted 1908 barn in Tiburon and a four-bedroom home in Geyserville.

author: By The New York Times
title: Biden Calls Putin a War Criminal After Images from Bucha Surface
description: President Biden said reports of indiscriminate killings of civilians in the town of Bucha, Ukraine, constituted a “war crime” and that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia should face charges.
content: President Biden said reports of indiscriminate killings of civilians in the town of Bucha, Ukraine, constituted a “war crime” and that President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia should face charges.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Senate Committee Votes on Jackson Nomination
description: Senators on the Judiciary Committee deadlocked 11 to 11 along party lines in the evenly divided chamber, forcing Democrats to take extra steps in the full Senate to keep Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court on track.
content: Senators on the Judiciary Committee deadlocked 11 to 11 along party lines in the evenly divided chamber, forcing Democrats to take extra steps in the full Senate to keep Ketanji Brown Jackson’s confirmation to the Supreme Court on track.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Horrified by the Killing of Civilians in Ukraine
description: Readers urge stronger intervention and steep penalties for any war crimes. Also: Politicians, act for us; balloons’ peril; tenant evictions; smashing rackets.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook Right Now
description: On culinary wanderlust, with recipes for fried fish, savory bread pudding and more.
content: Good morning. “We domestic sensualists live in a state of longing, no matter how comfortable our own places are,” Laurie Colwin wrote in “The Lone Pilgrim,” and I often think about that when I’m cooking. I could be, for instance, halfway through the preparation of Heston Blumenthal’s magical recipe for fried fish with vodka and beer batter (above) and realize, deep in my bones, that what I really desire is kimchi grilled cheese, or chicken paprikash.
source.name: The New York Times
